history.content:
The workload is a step up from the other 61 series. There are labs, homeworks, and projects and each take a significant amount of time to complete.

The workload is a step up from the other 61 series. There are labs, homeworks, and projects and each take a significant amount of time to complete.

children.subject: In my experience, taking 61C with Garcia was a similar workload to 61B and 70. I think the hardest thing to get used to (for me, at least) was that the projects and homeworks give you a lot less instruction on what you're supposed to do. Most of the time, you're given a spec that tells you what to do, but with no real instruction on how to do it, which is up to you to figure out. Labs also usually were a little bit harder than 61B.

61C is probably the highest workload class I've ever taken, a lot more work than 61B since 61B has only 4 projects, while 61C has a lot more and they are not easy. In 61B you only need to learn Java but in 61C you need to learn C, RISC-V, logisim, SIMD, OpenMP, Spark, Go... Lots of languages and tools.

history.content:
CS Minor here. MCB major.

I've taken: CS 61A, 61B. Currently taking 70.

What is the workload for CS 61C (Dan Garcia) like? I've searched previous posts for this, but I'd like to hear more opinions of how it compares to Hilfinger's CS 61B or CS 70 (Rao/Babak) in terms of project/homework workload and conceptual difficulty.

How hard is it to get an A? Comparison to 70 would be helpful...or 61B (Hilfinger).
history.subject: Advice on CS 61C Workload
